metadata.title: Engineered niches support the development of human dendritic cells 1 in humanized mice

abstract.text: Classical dendritic cells (cDCs) are rare sentinel cells specialized in the regulation of adaptive 25 immunity. Modeling cDC development is both crucial to study cDCs and harness their 26 potential in immunotherapy. Here we addressed whether cDCs could differentiate in response 27 to trophic cues delivered by mesenchymal components of the hematopoietic niche where they 28 physiologically develop and maintain. We found that expression of the membrane bound 29 form of human FLT3L and SCF together with CXCL12 in a bone marrow mesenchymal 30 stromal cell line is sufficient to induce the contact-dependent specification of both type 1 and 31 type 2 cDCs from CD34 + hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs). Engraftment of 32 these engineered mesenchymal stromal cells (eMSCs) together with CD34 + HSPCs creates an 33 in vivo synthetic niche in the dermis of immunodeficient mice. Cell-to-cell contact between 34 HSPCs and stromal cells within these organoids drive the local specification of cDCs and 35 CD123 + AXL + CD327 + pre/AS-DCs. cDCs generated in vivo display higher levels of 36 resemblance with human blood cDCs unattained by in vitro generated subsets. Altogether, 37 eMSCs provide a novel and unique platform recapitulating the full spectrum of cDC subsets 38 enabling their functional characterization in vivo. 39 40 41

body_text.text: Classical human dendritic cells (cDCs) are sentinels of the immune system with a unique 44 ability to regulate the function of T lymphocytes 1 . Dendritic cells can induce immune 45 tolerance 2 or drive the development of immunity 3 . 46 The analysis of blood circulating subsets has revealed that cDCs consist in two major 47 subtypes: CD141 + XCR1 + Clec9A + DCs (cDC1) and CD1c + CD11c + CD172a (SIRPa) + DCs 48 (cDC2s) 4-6 . Both cDC1s and cDC2s arise from a bone marrow committed progenitor 7 or 49 from early IRF8 + multipotent progenitors 8, 9 , which generate a common circulating precursor 50 10 that progressively diverge in pre-cDC1s and pre-cDC2s 10-12 . Type 1 DCs are conserved 51 between mouse and human, and they share the expression of specific surface markers such as 52 Clec9A 13 and XCR1 5 as well as the transcription factor (TF) IRF8, which is essential for the 53 development of murine cDC1s 4-6, 13-15 . Conversely, human CD1c + type 2 DCs have been 54 shown to express the IRF4 TF 16 , which controls the development of their phenotypic 55 equivalent in the mouse model 16, 17 . This rather simple picture is complicated by the diversity 56 of CD1c + cells, which encompass migratory DCs as well as CD14 int inflammatory DCs 57 recruited during inflammation [18] [19] [20] . More recently, un-biased approaches have uncovered a 58 deeper complexity in the DC network with the identification of 2 types of cDC2s with 59 distinct transcriptional profiles and the identification of AXL + CD11c + CD1c + cells which 60 have been proposed to act as a precursor for cDCs 12, 21 . other niche factors 28 . At steady state, Flt3-ligand (FLT3L) is delivered as a membrane-bound 67 precursor expressed on radio-resistant stromal cells [29] [30] [31] . After egressing from the bone 68 marrow, DC precursors circulate in the blood and seed the peripheral tissues 32 . In the lymph 69 node, stromal fibroblastic reticular cells provide FLT3L 33 , and FLT3-dependent proliferation 70 of cDC in periphery is required for their maintenance 34, 35 . 71 Modelling the development of cDCs in culture systems is instrumental to better understand 72 their ontogeny and define their immunological function. Pioneer work from Banchereau et al. 73 have identified that GMCSF and TNF-a cooperate to produce CD1a + cells with features of Here we aimed at modeling human cDC development by providing physiological factors 92 associated to hematopoietic niches. We found that engineered mesenchymal stromal cells 93 (eMSCs) expressing a combination of membrane-bound FLT3L and SCF/KITL together with 94 CXCL12 provide a scaffold for human cDC differentiation. Engraftment of eMSCs along 95 with CD34 + HSPCs leads to the local development of cDCs in immunodeficient mice. This in 96 vivo system recapitulates the differentiation of pre/AS-DCs, cDC1s and cDC2s with an 97 unreached level of similarity with the phenotype of human blood cDCs.

Stromal membrane-bound FLT3L is sufficient to support human cDC differentiation 100 from CD34 + HSPCs 101 We hypothesized that the interaction of hematopoietic progenitors with membrane bound 102 factors expressed by stromal cells of the niche would promote the specification of the cDC 103 lineage.

To test this, we engineered a bone marrow-derived murine mesenchymal cell line (MS5) 7 53 105 to stably and homogeneously express the transmembrane form of human FLT3L (MS5_F) as 106 probed by flow cytometry (Fig. 1a) . Co-culture of MS5_F with CD34 + HSPCs drives the 107 appearance of cDC1-like Clec9A + CD141 + and cDC2-like CD14 -CD1c + cells. Importantly, 108 MS5_F is more efficient than recombinant soluble FLT3L (MS5+recFL) in generating cDC-109 like cells (Fig. 1b) .

In contrast, OP9 54 hematogenic stromal cells stably expressing membrane bound FLT3L 111 (OP9_F) were less efficient than MS5_F in driving cDC differentiation (Fig. 1c) . Besides, 112 MS5_F also promoted the appearance of CD123 + CD303/4 + cells resembling either pDCs or 113 pre/AS-DCs 12, 21 (Supplementary Fig.1a and b) . 114 Next, we wanted to test whether cell-to-cell interactions mediate the differentiation of cDCs 115 driven by FLT3L-expressing MS5 stromal cells. Using transwell permeable to soluble factors 116 but preventing cognate interactions, we found that direct contact is required to support 117 efficiently cDC differentiation (Fig. 1d) . 118 Collectively, these data show that membrane FLT3L expression in stromal cells provide an 119 improved platform to trigger the differentiation of cDC-like cells from CD34 + HSPCs in vitro 120 via cell-to-cell contact. 124 Next, we sought to improve the efficiency of cDC production in MS5_F by co-expressing 125 additional niche factors. We focused on SCF, CXCL12 and TPO because of their essential 126 role in supporting HSPCs maintenance in the bone marrow niche 22, 24-27, 55 . SCF had also 127 been extensively used in previously published DC culture protocols 7, 39, 40, 56 .

To this end, we generated a collection of MS5 stromal cells stably expressing either one, two, 129 three or four human factors by combining CXCL12, TPO and membrane-bound SCF/KITL, 130 with or without membrane-bound FLT3L ( Supplementary Fig. 2a) . 131 We screened this collection of engineered mesenchymal stromal cell (eMSC) lines based on 132 their ability to support human cDC differentiation from cord blood-derived CD34 + HSPCs.

At day 15, only FLT3L-expressing eMSCs successfully supported the differentiation of 134 CD141 + Clec9A + and CD14 -CD1c + cells ( Fig. 2a and Supplementary Fig. 3a) . We conclude 135 that FLT3L is necessary for the differentiation of cDCs using eMSCs. Besides, optimal cDC 136 production was obtained in cultures containing eMSC co-expressing membrane bound SCF 137 and CXCL12 together with FLT3L (MS5_FS12) (Fig. 2a) , whereas no difference was 138 observed for CD14 + CD16monocytes and CD14 + CD16 + macrophages as compared to 139 MS5_CTRL ( Supplementary Fig. 3b ).

Furthermore, we noticed that in vitro differentiated CD14 -CD1c + cDC2-like cells were 141 heterogeneous for the expression of the mannose receptor CD206 (Fig. 2a) . Circulating blood 142 cDC2s do not generally express CD206 ( Supplementary Fig. 3c ) whereas CD206 is a marker 143 of skin and migratory cDC2 19, 57 .

Most of the previously described protocols to generate human DC-like cells in vitro from 145 8 both CD14 + monocytes and CD34 + HSPCs made an extensive use of the cytokine GM-CSF 7, 146 8, 37, 39, 40, 56 , with one exception 49 . Since we did not include GM-CSF in our protocol, we 147 wanted to assess whether human GM-CSF was spontaneously produced in CD34 + cultures. 148 We could not detect any GM-CSF from co-culture supernatant (Fig. 2b) . Accordingly, GM-149 CSF blocking antibody did not impact the generation of cDCs driven by MS5_FS12 (Fig.   150 2c). We conclude that GM-CSF is dispensable for the generation of cDCs in vitro, as 151 previously reported both in mouse 58, 59 and human 49 . 152 We also observed that MS5_FS12 stromal cells significantly improve the differentiation of 153 CD123 + CD303/4 + cells (Fig. 3a) , a phenotype shared by both plasmacytoid DC and pre/AS- Human DCs generated in vitro using MS5_FS12 align with circulating blood DCs 168 In order to validate the identity of the cDCs generated using the MS5_FS12 stromal niche, 169 9 we compared the transcriptome (RNA-seq) and phenotype (CyTOF) of in vitro differentiated 170 subsets to circulating blood cDC1s and cDC2s ( Fig. 4a-f ).

Hierarchical clustering of RNA-seq data revealed that subsets generated in culture maintain a 172 strong "culture imprinting" (Supplementary Fig. 4a ). Indeed, we could identify a 2000 genes 173 signature (1000 genes up and 1000 genes down-regulated), which clearly separates in vitro 174 generated cells from circulating blood subsets regardless of their subset identity 175 ( Supplementary Fig. 4b ). The majority of these genes were associated to cell cycle and 176 metabolism as shown by pathways enrichment analysis ( Supplementary Fig. 4c ).

Nonetheless, once this "in vitro culture signature" was subtracted from the total protein 178 coding genes, CD141 + Clec9A + and CD1c + CD206 +/cells generated in culture 179 transcriptionally align to blood cDC1 and cDC2, respectively (Fig. 4a) . CD1c + cells have recently been shown to contain two distinct subsets termed as cDC2 and 186 cDC3 21 . Alignment of cultured cells was probed towards total CD1c + cells (CD1c>cDC1), 187 cDC2 (cDC2>ALL and cDC2>DC3) and DC3 signatures (DC3>cDC2 and DC3>ALL). We 188 found that in vitro generated CD141 + Clec9A + and CD1c + CD206 +/cells are enriched in genes 189 defining circulating blood cDC1 and cDC2, respectively (Fig. 4b) . The expression of the top 190 50 genes for each signature in the differentiated subsets further supports this conclusion (Fig.   191 4c). Importantly, both CD206 + and CD206subsets aligned preferentially to cDC2 as 192 compared to DC3 and cDC1 ( Fig. 4b and Supplementary Fig. 4d ). CD163 was recently 193 described as a marker selectively expressed in blood cDC3 as compared to cDC2 21 .

Supporting our previous conclusion, CD163 was neither expressed in CD1c + CD206nor in 195 CD1c + CD206 + cells generated in vitro, while CD163 + cells were detected among CD14 + 196 monocytes and CD14 + CD16 + macrophages ( Supplementary Fig. 4e ).
To obtain a more exhaustive characterization of the phenotype of in vitro generated subsets 198 we performed CyTOF analysis using a panel of 38 metal-conjugated monoclonal antibodies.

Dimension reduction of the CyTOF data was performed using the Uniform Manifold However, the yield of in vitro generated cDC was significantly higher at day14, when most of 220 the cultures were therefore analyzed ( Supplementary Fig. 4i ).

Collectively, our data demonstrate that: i) in vitro generated CD141 + Clec9A + recapitulate the 222 phenotype of bona fide blood cDC1; ii) CD14 -CD1c + cells align to cDC2 regardless of their 223 CD206 expression; iii) CD123 + CD303 + cells contain some recently described pre-DC/AS-224 DC phenotypically and functionally distinct from pDCs. However, we identified two major 232 We next wanted to assess whether we could use MS5_FS12 to recapitulate a more 233 physiological niche microenvironment supporting human HSPCs maintenance in vivo. 234 To this end, we designed an experimental strategy based on the subcutaneous injection of 235 cord blood-derived CD34 + HSPCs together with MS5_FS12 in a basement membrane matrix 236 (Matrigel) in NSG mice (Fig. 5a ).

Clusters of cells embedded in Matrigel can be identified as early as day 12 by tissue histology 238 (Fig. 5b) . Flow cytometry analysis demonstrated that MS5_FS12 but not MS5_CTRL 239 induced the expansion of human leukocytes within the Matrigel plugs (Fig. 5c ). We then 240 tested whether cell-to-cell interactions of eMSC with human progenitors play a role in this 241 process. We injected two independent plugs of CD34 + HSPCs with either MS5_CTRL or 242 MS5_FS12 in the same recipient mouse (contralateral plugs) (Fig. 5d ). We found a relative The MS5_FS12 niche efficiently supports human cDC1, cDC2, pre/AS-DC and pDC 263 development from CD34 + HSPCs in vivo 264 We investigated whether the engraftment of CD34 + HSPCs together with MS5_FS12 could 265 lead to the local differentiation of human DC subsets.

Flow cytometry analysis of Matrigel organoids demonstrates that the MS5_FS12 but not the 267 13 MS5_CTRL niche specifically supports the differentiation of CD141 + Clec9A + cDC1-like 268 cells and CD14 -CD1c + cDC2-like cells ( Fig. 6a and Supplementary Fig. 6a ). This finding was 269 supported by immunofluorescence staining on plug sections highlighting the occurrence of 270 human CD45 cells expressing either Clec9A or CD1c (Fig. 6b) .

Further analysis revealed the expansion of CD123 + CD303/4 + cells in MS5_FS12 when 272 compared to MS5_CTRL plugs ( Fig. 6c and Supplementary Fig. 6a ). All these cells also 273 expressed CD45RA and heterogeneous levels of AXL and CD327, as previously described 274 for their in vitro counterparts (Fig. 6c) . However, only MS5_FS12 induced a strong 275 accumulation of AXL + CD327 + pre/AS-DC expressing various levels of CD1c (Fig. 6c) . In 276 addition, bona fide CD123 + CD45RA + AXL -CD327 lo/-pDCs could also be detected (Fig. 6c) .

RNA-seq analysis of in vivo generated CD123 + AXL -CD327 lo/and CD123 + AXL + CD327 + 278 cells further support this conclusion and unequivocally align them to blood circulating pDC 279 and AS-DC, respectively (Fig. 6d) . Supplementary Fig. 6c ). On the contrary, pDC were not significantly increased in the same 291 comparison ( Fig. 6f and Supplementary Fig. 6c ). We conclude that local cues associated to 292 14 the MS5_FS12 niche control cDC lineage commitment. In support of this view, we could not 293 detect a systemic increase in the levels of serum FLT3L in mice carrying engineered stromal 294 cell plugs (Fig. 6g) . Accordingly, spleen resident murine cDCs did not expand upon 295 MS5_FS12 engraftment while they massively do so upon administration of recombinant 296 soluble human FLT3L (Fig. 6g) . Together with the 2-plugs experiments (Fig. 6f) , these 297 observations suggest that most of the FLT3L aegis relies on its membrane bound form Table 6 ).

Moreover, we found that: i) AXL + Siglec6 + pre/AS-DCs generated in vivo (or in vitro) align 331 to their primary counterparts and selectively express a signature that distinguish them from 332 bona fide pDCs (DAB2, CD22, ADLH2 e.g.) (Fig. 7c) . ii) conversely, AXL -Siglec6bona fide 333 pDCs generated in vivo (or in vitro) align to their primary counterparts and express high 334 levels of markers distinguishing them from pre/AS-DCs (IRF7, GZMB, TCF4, BCL11A, e.g.) 335 (Fig. 7c) . iii) cDC2s generated in vivo (in NSG mice organoids carrying MS5_FS12) had 336 higher levels of similarity with blood cDC2s (including higher expression of BTLA, FCER1A, 337 e.g.) (Fig. 7b, 7d and 7e) . Recently, both CD5 + and CD5 -cDC2s subsets have been reported 338 in human blood 65, 66 and we found that in vivo generated cDC2s aligned particularly well 339 with blood CD5 + cDC2s (with the expression of CD5, CD2, e.g.) (Fig. 7b and 7e) . By 340 contrast, in vitro generated cDC2s expressed high levels of activation genes such MHC 341 molecules (HLA-DR, DQ, e.g.); co-stimulatory molecules (CD80, CD40, e.g.), activation 342 markers (ETS2, CCR6, CCR7, CXCL13, CCL22, e.g.) (Fig. 7e and 7f) and genes associated 343 with type I and type II interferon pathways (STAT1, IRF9, IGS15, GBP1, e.g.) 344 (Supplementary Fig. 7d and Supplementary Table 6 ).

All together, we conclude that MS5_FS12-containing organoids provide a unique scaffold for (Fig. 8a) . We then performed a mixed leukocyte reaction (MLR) by co-culturing CD4 + naïve T cells proliferation (Fig. 8b) , as expected and reported for circulating blood 367 cDC2 12, 21 (Supplementary Fig. 8b) . Conversely, pDC were significantly less effective on 368 triggering T cells activation, as shown by the consistent reduction in the frequency of 369 dividing CD4 + T cells when compared to cDC2 and pre/AS-DC (Fig. 8b) . Frozen samples were shipped to GENEWIZ ® where they were processed. RNA was extracted 546 and libraries were prepared using an ultra-low input RNA library preparation kit (Illumina).
Libraries were sequenced on HiSeq2500 (Illumina).

The raw sequencing data was initially aligned on the human reference genome hg38 using 549 STAR aligner (v2.5.3a) 76 . Raw read counts matrix was made by STAR (with the option - Table 4 ). Briefly, the transciptome of blood cDC1s and blood CD1c + cells was taken from 567 previously published data sets 63 . cDC1>CD1c + and CD1c + >cDC1 signatures were defined

FIGREF0.text: Human hematopoietic progenitors reside in the stem cells niche of the bone marrow. Genetic 62 studies in the murine model identified three essential factors supporting HSPCs homeostasis: 63 the membrane-bound form of stem cell factor (SCF/KITL) 22, 23 , the C-X-C motive 64 chemokine 12 (CXCL12) 24, 25 and thrombopoietin (TPO) 26, 27 . In the bone marrow, 65 perivascular mesenchymal stromal cells have been described as the main source of SCF and 66 4

FIGREF1.text: Langerhans cells from CD34 + hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs) 36 . Sallusto75 et al. have shown that GMCSF and IL-4 induce the differentiation of CD1c + CD1a + 76 inflammatory DCs from CD14 monocytes 37 . More recent work has demonstrated that FLT3L 77 (with TPO or with SCF/KITL, GM-CSF and IL-4) is instrumental in generating CD141 + 78 cDC1s aligning phenotypically and functionally with cDC1s 7, 8, 38-40 . This is in line with the 79 crucial role of FLT3L, engaging the Flt3 receptor tyrosine kinase 41-43 in controlling DC 80 homeostasis both in mice 32, 34, 44, 45 and humans 10, 29, 46, 47 . Moreover, the activation of Notch 81 signaling pathway has been shown to further improve the in vitro differentiation of both 82 human and mouse cDC1s 48, 49 . Despite the successes in modeling cDC1 differentiation in 83 vitro, CD1c + cells found in culture of CD34 + HSPCs either align poorly with bona fide blood 84 circulating cDC2s 39 or were not extensively characterized 48, 49 . 85 Recapitulating human cDC development in vivo has the potential to greatly improve our 86 understanding of DC biology and facilitate its translational applications. Human cDCs have 87 been found in stably reconstituted humanized mice treated with supraphysiological 88 concentration of human FLT3L 29, 50, 51 . However, the generated CD11c + CD141 + and 89 CD11c + CD1c + cells were poorly characterized and their dissemination to peripheral tissues 90 has rarely been assessed 52 .91 5

FIGREF3.text: and membrane bound SCF improve FLT3L-driven development of 123 human cDC in vitro

FIGREF4.text: 21 . A more refined phenotypic characterization of the in vitro generated cells also shows 155 that all CD123 + cells express high levels of CD45RA, and they can be subdivided in AXL -156 CD327 lo/and AXL + CD327 + subsets, phenotypically aligning to pDC and pre/AS-DC (Fig. 157 3b). This conclusion was further supported by gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) 60 of 158 RNA-sequencing data, displaying a significant enrichment of previously reported pDC and 159 AS-DC gene signatures 21 in in vitro generated AXL -CD327 lo/and AXL + CD327 + , 160 respectively(Fig. 3c). Moreover, only the AXL -CD327 lo/cells were capable to produce type 161 I interferon in response to TLR stimulation, a specific feature of bona fide pDC which is not 162 shared with pre/AS-DC 12, 21(Fig. 3d).

FIGREF5.text: In conclusion, we identified the combination of membrane-bound FLT3L, SCF and CXCL12 164 (MS5_FS12) as the most efficient tested condition to support human DCs differentiation in 165 vitro from CD34 + HSPCs.

FIGREF7.text: To further validate the similarity of in vitro generated cells with physiologically circulating181 subsets we performed gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) 60, 61 using the BubbleGum 182 software 62 . This methodology enables to score the enrichment of a signature in a pairwise 183 comparison of two transcriptomes. We scored cDC1 alignment using gene signatures specific 184 for blood cDC1 obtained from published datasets (cDC1>CD1c + 63 and DC1>ALL 21 ). CD14 -185

FIGREF8.text: Approximation and Projection (UMAP) algorithm 64 . UMAP plots display clusters of cells 201 that were expanded upon MS5_FS12 co-culture as compare to MS5_CTRL(Fig. 4d).202Clec9A + CD141 + cells identified by flow cytometry were shown to also express CADM1 and 203 CD26 further aligning them with blood cDC1s (red cluster,Fig. 4d-f). CD14 -CD1c + cells did204 not express high level of monocyte markers such as CD64, CD68 and CD16 while they 205 appeared heterogeneous for CD206 expression (blue cluster, Fig. 4d-f and Supplementary 206 Fig. 4f). Of note, CD14 -CD1c + cells generated in culture did not express high level of 207 FceRIa, CD172a and CD5 found in blood cDC2s (Supplementary Fig. 4f). By contrast they 208 are strongly positive for CD86 and CD80 unlike their circulating counterpart (Supplementary 209 Fig. 4f). In addition, CD123 + CD303 + cells were shown to express heterogeneous levels of 210 pre-DC markers such as CD327 and CX3CR1 and moderate level of AXL (green cluster, Fig. 211 4d-f and Supplementary Fig. 4f), in line with flow cytometry analysis highlighting the 212 presence of both pDC and pre/AS-DC within CD123 + CD303 + cells generated in vitro (Fig. 213 3b). On the other hand, by combining flow and mass cytometry analysis we were able to 214 show that MS5_FS12 stromal cells do not support lymphoid development (Fig. 4d and 215 Supplementary Fig. 4g). Indeed, the remaining cells (other than DC) present in culture 216 consist of CD15 + Granulocytes and CD14 + CD16 +/-Monocytes/Macrophages (Supplementary 217Fig. 4h). Finally, the analysis of in vitro cDC differentiation kinetics revealed that both cDC1 218 and cDC2 can be detected in MS5_FS12 cultures as early as day7(Supplementary Fig. 4i).

FIGREF10.text: 225 limitations of the in vitro culture. First, the culture system imposes a strong transcriptional 226 imprinting throughout subsets. Second, in vitro generated cDC2s failed to express to full 227 phenotypic profile of blood cDC2s.228 229 Subcutaneous engraftment of MS5_FS12 in NSG mice results in the formation of a 230 "synthetic niche" supporting human CD34 + progenitor local maintenance, differentiation 231 and expansion

FIGREF11.text: FLT3L and SCF together with CXCL12 define an efficient in vivo niche by 247 delivering cell-to-cell contacts supporting HSPCs expansion. Supporting this hypothesis, we 248 found that MS5_FS12 expressing GFP persist in the plugs at day 12 of differentiation (Fig. 249 5e). Immunofluorescence analysis further supported this observation and demonstrated the 250 existence of cell-to-cell contact between MS5_FS12 and human CD45 + leukocytes (Fig. 5e 251 and Supplementary Fig. 5a). Leukocytes expressing CD34 + could also be detected, 252 supporting the notion that a pool of undifferentiated progenitors is maintained in the 253 MS5_FS12 organoids at day 12 (Fig. 5e). Of note, Matrigel plugs contained some mouse 254 CD31 + cells suggesting undergoing vascularization as evidenced by the formation of early 255 tube-like structure (Fig. 5f). However, no vascular leak was observed, as demonstrated by the 256 absence of intravenously delivered CTV + CD3 + cells in the subcutaneous plug 257 (Supplementary Fig. 5b). 258 Taken together, these data show that engineered stromal cells MS5_FS12 provide a minimal 259 synthetic niche scaffold supporting human CD34 + HSPCs maintenance and expansion in 260 vivo. 261 262

FIGREF12.text: To further refine the phenotypic characterization of HLA-DR + mononuclear phagocytes in 281 MS5_FS12 organoids we performed high-dimensional mass cytometry analysis. The282 comparison of MS5_FS12 with MS5_CTRL plugs highlighted the expansion of all subsets 283 previously identified by flow cytometry: cDC1s, cDC2s, pre/AS-DCs, pDCs and a distinct 284 population of CD33 + CCR2 + CX3CR1 + Clec12A + myeloid cells (Fig. 6e and Supplementary 285 Fig. 6b). We next wanted to determine whether commitment towards the cDC lineage would 286 be dependent on local developmental cues and possibly cell-to-cell contact between CD34 + 287HSPCs and MS5_FS12. To this end, we engrafted mice with two distal organoids, one 288 containing MS5_CTRL and the second one containing MS5_FS12. We found that cDC1, 289 cDC2 and pre/AS-DCs were selectively expanded in MS5_FS12 plugs (Fig. 6f and 290

FIGREF13.text: 298 delivered in the context of eMSCs. Of note, administration of recombinant soluble FLT3L 299 was poorly efficient at expanding human DCs populations in Matrigel organoids formed with 300 control stromal cells (Fig. 6g). This demonstrates the superiority of local, cell-associated cues 301 (MS5_FS12, i.e.) to achieve the expansion of human cDCs in the dermis of NSG mice. 302 A more extensive characterization of MS5_FS12 organoids revealed the presence of myeloid 303 lineages other than DCs, such as CD14 + CD16monocyte-like cells and CD15 + granulocytes 304 (Fig. 6h and Supplementary Fig. 6d). Conversely, no lymphoid specification was observed 305(Fig. 6h and Supplementary Fig. 6d). Despite this broad spectrum of lineages, CD34 + HSPCs 306 represented the most abundant population at day 12(Fig. 6h). This observation suggests that 307 the MS5_FS12 niche combines HSPC maintenance with lineage commitment.

FIGREF14.text: in vivo more faithfully align to blood circulating cDC2s310    Finally, we wanted to establish whether in vivo differentiated DCs in MS5_FS12 organoids 311 had a distinct phenotype from the subsets generated in vitro in MS5_FS12 co-culture.312UMAP plots of CyTOF analysis revealed three major findings. First, pre/AS-DCs represent a 313 more abundant population in vivo (Fig. 7aandSupplementary Fig. 7a). Second, both cDC1 314 generated in vitro and in vivo fully align phenotypically, displaying a strong expression of 315 CADM1 and CD26 (Fig. 7aandSupplementary Fig. 7a). Third, unlike cDC1, cDC2 316 generated in vivo exhibit noticeable phenotypic differences. In vivo-generated cDC2 express 317 higher levels of FceRIa, CD172a and CD5 while showing lower expression of HLA-DR and 318 CD86 (Fig. 7b and Supplementary Fig. 7b). The specific phenotype conferred by the 319 MS5_FS12 niche education renders cDC2s more akin to their blood counterparts. In order to320 compare extensively the transcriptional landscape of in vivo (NSG organoids) generated DCs 321 with primary DCs found in human blood, we performed RNAseq analysis on FACS-sorted 322 cDC2s obtained after the enzymatic digestion of MS5_FS12-containing plugs or purified 323 from human blood. 324 As previously observed for in vitro generated cells, the MS5_FS12 niche confers an in vivo 325 imprinting resulting in the differential expression of 2872 genes (up-or down-regulated) in in 326 vivo versus ex vivo isolated subsets (Supplementary Fig. 7c). Pathway analysis revealed that 327 this in vivo bias was mainly due to upregulation of genes associated with DNA replication, 328 cell cycle and proliferation (MYC, CDC6/7, POLA2, MCM6/7 e.g.) (Supplementary Fig. 7c329 and Supplementary

FIGREF15.text: 346 the specification and commitment of the DC lineage. This unique and versatile system 347 bypasses the limitation of in vitro cultures, which generated inefficiently pre/AS-DCs and 348 biased the differentiation of cDC2s toward an activated phenotype. Collectively, MS5_FS12 349 organoids faithfully recapitulate the differentiation of DCs with an unattained level of 350 similarity to human blood DCs, especially blood cDC2s.351 352 cDC2 generated in vitro and in vivo recapitulate functional features ascribed to blood 353 cDC2 354 In the last set of experiments, we aimed at functionally validate cord blood-derived cDC 355 generated in the MS5_FS12 stromal niche. Moreover, we also assessed whether the 356 phenotypic differences observed in cDC2 generated in vitro and in vivo may impact their 357 function. 358 We first confirmed in vitro the responsiveness of cord blood-derived cDC2 to TLR agonists 359 expressed in human circulating cDC2, as demonstrated by the up-regulation of maturation 360 markers (i.e. HLA-DR, CD86 and CD83) in response to TLR4 (LPS) and TLR8 (VTX) 361 stimulation

FIGREF16.text: 362CTV-labeled allogeneic naïve T cells together with FACS-sorted cDC subsets363 (Supplementary Fig. 8a) activated overnight with a TLR agonists cocktail comprising of LPS 364 (TLR4), R848 (TLR7/8) and Poly(I:C) (TLR3). After 7 days of culture, we observed that 365 both in vitro and in vivo generated cDC2 and pre/AS-DC were capable to efficiently induce 366

FIGREF17.text: Importantly, only cDC2 were able to produce high amounts of T cell-polarizing cytokines in 371 response to TLR stimulation, as demonstrated by intracellular TNFa and IL-12 detection by 372 flow cytometry(Fig. 8c). All these features demonstrate that cDC2s, pDCs and pre/AS-DCs 373 functionally align to their in vivo counterparts as previously described in the literature 12, 21 .374 Collectively, our data suggest that: i) both in vitro and in vivo differentiated cDC2 are equally 375 capable to induce CD4 + T cells activation as well as produce large amounts of TNF-a and IL-376 12; ii) pre/AS-DC are as efficient as cDC2 in activating allogeneic naïve CD4+ T cells in 377 vitro, a distinctive feature that clearly separate them from the pDC lineage; iii) despite their 378 ability to induce CD4 + T cell proliferation in MLR settings, pre/AS-DC do not produce high 379 levels of cytokines commonly associated with cDC2 function, such as TNF-a or IL-12.

FIGREF18.text: last two decades, DC-based strategies have been proposed for the therapeutic 383 vaccination against cancer, including (i) non-targeted protein-based vaccines captured by 384 DCs in vivo, (ii) specific targeting of DC subsets with mAb coupled to tumor antigens 67 and 385 (iii) antigen loading of ex vivo generated dendritic cells 3 . In this context, experimental 386 models recapitulating the development of human DC subsets are crucially needed. 387 Here we describe a novel approach to model human DC development from CD34 + HSPCs 388 both in vitro and in vivo. To this end, we primarily focused on the physiological niches where 389 human DCs differentiate and maintain: a central bone marrow niche where DC progenitors 390 are specified and peripheral niches in the lymph nodes where DCs reside. 391 Previous studies have shown that the cell-to-cell interaction with membrane-bound factors 392 expressed by the niche microenvironment plays an essential role in HSPCs maintenance and 393 expansion 22, 23, 68, 69 . Alternative splicing of human and murine SCF transcript results in the 394 synthesis of both a soluble and a membrane-bound non-cleavable form of the protein.

FIGREF19.text: Interestingly, the secreted form of SCF/KITLG is not sufficient for the establishment of a 396 functional niche in murine bone marrow 22, 23 whereas the expression of human membrane-397 bound SCF is sufficient to support human myeloid development in humanized mice 69 . We398 therefore wanted to test whether a similar relationship might exist between the soluble and 399 membrane-bound forms of human FLT3L. Consistent with this hypothesis, the expression of 400 transmembrane FLT3L in mesenchymal stromal cells (MS5_F) improved the efficiency of 401 DC differentiation in vitro, as compared to its soluble form (MS5+recFL). Moreover, the 402 engraftment of distal organoids (MS5_CTRL vs MS5_FS12) together with the comparison of 403 local (membrane bound) vs systemic (soluble) delivery of human FLT3L in vivo, supported 404 the notion that cell-associated FLT3L delivered by engineered stromal cells significantly 405 improves the development of human DCs in NSG mice. 406 Several protocols have been proposed for the in vitro differentiation of human cDCs from 407 CD34 + HSPCs 7, 38-40, 48, 49 . In vitro differentiated cDC1s have been shown to fully 408 recapitulate both the phenotype and function of circulating bona fide blood cDC1s 8, 39, 48, 49 409 including high levels of IRF8 expression and Batf3-dependency in vitro 13 , as well as IRF8-410 dependancy both in vivo 70 and in vitro 48 . Conversely, several aspects have limited an 411 exhaustive validation of in vitro generated CD1c + cDC2-like cells such as the expression of 412 CD14 7 , the transcriptional alignment with monocyte-derived DCs (moDCs) 39 or the lack of 413 a high-dimensional phenotypic characterization 48, 49 . 414 Here we described a new system (MS5_FS12), which efficiently supports the differentiation 415 of both CD141 + Clec9A + cDC1s and CD14 -CD1c + cDC2s. However, cDC2s generated in 416 MS5_FS12 cultures only partially recapitulate the phenotype of circulating blood cDC2s, as 417 suggested by the lack of expression of cDC2-specific markers such as FceRIa and CD5.418 Nevertheless, engineered MSCs display the unique advantage of being suitable for in vivo 419 applications. 420 Immunodeficient mice provide a unique system to model the onset of human immune 421 responses in realistic settings 71 . However, a reliable method to achieve the differentiation of 422 human DCs in vivo has not been described, yet. Current protocols rely on the engraftment of 423 human CD34 + HSPCs in sub-lethally irradiated immunodeficient mice (humanized mice). 424 This strategy has not been successful in the generation of well-characterized circulating DC 425 subsets 71 . Administration of supraphysiological levels of recombinant FLT3L has been 426 shown to stimulate cDC differentiation upon reconstitution of NSG 29, 50 or Flt3 -/-BRGS 51 427 mice with human CD34 + HSPCs. However, the phenotype of CD141 + cDC1s and CD1c + 428 cDC2s was poorly characterized and, despite exceptions 52 , tissue DCs were not generally 429 investigated. These aspects represent an important limitation by precluding, for instance, the 430 20 modeling of skin vaccination. Alternatively, transgenic mice expressing human GM-CSF and 431 IL-3 (in the presence or absence of human SCF), either constitutively 72, 73 or by replacing 432 their murine counterparts (knock-in) 74 , have been generated. Despite displaying higher levels 433 of myeloid reconstitution, as well as the presence of human alveolar macrophages in the 434 lungs of humanized mice 74 , this approach did not improve the development of human cDCs 435 in lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues of engrafted animals. 436 We demonstrated that MS5_FS12 support the differentiation of human cDCs in vivo in 437 subcutaneous organoids in NSG mice. High-dimensional mass cytometry (Cytof) and 438 transcriptomic (RNA-seq) analysis of in vivo generated cells confirmed their phenotypic and 439 transcriptional alignment to circulating blood cDC1s and cDC2s. More importantly, cDC2s 440 generated in vivo better resemble their physiologically circulating counterparts by expressing 441 higher levels of FceRIa, CD172a, CD5, CD2 and BTLA when compared to in vitro 442 differentiated cells. The lower expression of activation markers such as CD86, CD80 and 443 MHC molecules also suggests that in vivo cDC2s displayed a less mature phenotype than in 444 vitro generated cells. 445 Moreover, MS5_FS12 niche was capable of supporting the local maintenance and expansion 446 of human HSPCs as well as pre/AS-DCs, resulting in the persistence of a long-lasting source 447 of progenitors capable of undergoing DC differentiation. To our knowledge, this is the first 448 time that a well-characterized system supporting the development of human pre/AS-DC is 449 reported. 450 Collectively, we have demonstrated that the engineered stromal cells MS5_FS12 give rise to 451 a synthetic hematopoietic niche when injected subcutaneously in NSG mice. The niche 452 microenvironment efficiently supports the expansion of CD34 + HSPCs, and human DCs 453 subsets (cDC1, cDC2 and pre/AS-DC) can be detected as early as day 12 in a radiation-free 454 environment. Importantly, in vitro culture system imposes a certain level of spontaneous 455 21 activation that is not found in primary circulating blood DCs. Differentiation of human cDCs 456 within humanized mice limit this phenomenon and make cDCs more similar to circulating 457 primary cDCs. Hence, this approach represents a versatile system to study human DC 458 development and function in vivo. in vivo experiments were performed using NOD.Cg-Prdc scid Il2rg tm1Wjl /SzJ (NSG) mice 462 (JAX #005557). All mice were used between 8 and 12 weeks of age. They were maintained 463 in specific-pathogen-free conditions and handled according to protocols approved by the UK 464 Home Office. 465 Generation of engineered MSCs 466 Human FLT3L, SCF and TPO were amplified by PCR from cDNA expression plasmids 467 (Origene) and cloned into pMX retroviral vectors (vectors details in Supplementary Table 1). 468 Lentiviral vector pBABE-puro-SDF-1 alpha was a gift from Bob Weinberg (Addgene 469 plasmid #12270) 75 . Viral particles were generated using the retroviral packaging plasmid 470 pCL-Ampho and a second generation lentiviral packaging system (psPAX2 and pMD2.G), 471 respectively. MS5 cells were first transduced with CXCL12 lentiviral vector and selected 472 using 15 µg/ml of Puromycin (Thermo Fisher). Then, a combination of single or multiple 473 cytokines were used to transduce MS5 cells as illustrated in Supplementary Fig. 2a. Cells 474 expressing human membrane bound FLT3L and SCF were sorted according to antibody 475 staining of the transmembrane proteins (antibodies listed in Supplementary Table 2). TPO-476 expressing cells were sorted according to the expression of mCherry reporter. 477 Flow cytometry and fluorescent-activated cell sorting (FACS) 478 Extracellular staining of cells was preformed in FACS buffer, consisting in PBS (Life 479 Technologies), 1% BSA (Apollo Scientific) and 2 mM EDTA (Life Technologies). For 480 intracellular staining, samples were fixed and permeabilized using the Cytofix/Cytoperm TM 481 kit (BD Biosciences) according to manufacturers' instructions. Antibodies used in all 482 experiments are listed in Supplementary Table 2. Flow cytometry analysis was performed on lines maintenance and primary cells isolation 487 MS5 53 and engineered mesenchymal stromal cell (eMSC) lines were cultured in IMDM (Life 488 Technologies) supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated FBS (Life Technologies), 489 penicillin/streptomycin (Life Technologies), 50 µM b-mercaptoethanol (Life Technologies) 490 and maintained at 37°C 5%CO2. OP9 and OP9_FLT3L were cultured in complete a-MEM 491 (Life Technologies) supplemented with 20% not heat-inactivated FBS, 492 penicillin/streptomycin, 50 µM b-mercaptoethanol and maintained at 37°C 5%CO2. 493 Cord blood units were obtained from Anthony Nolan Cell Therapy Centre (ANCTC). 494 Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were isolated by gradient centrifugation using 495 Ficoll-Paque (GE Healthcare) and CD34 + hematopoietic progenitors were isolated using 496 CD34 MicroBead Kit UltraPure (Miltenyi Biotec). 497 Adult peripheral blood was obtained from healthy volunteers from NHS Blood and 498 Transplant. PBMCs were isolated by Ficoll-Paque gradient centrifugation. Cells were 499 collected in FACS buffer and used for downstream applications.

FIGREF20.text: in vitro differentiation of human DCs, MS5, OP9 or eMSCs were seeded in a 96-well 502 plate (flat bottom) at a density of 10 4 cells/well. The following day, 10 4 cord blood-derived 503 CD34 + cells/well were seeded on top of stromal cells in complete IMDM (10% heat-504 inactivated FBS, penicillin/streptomycin, 50 µM b-mercaptoethanol) and maintained at 37°C 505 5% CO2. Half of the medium was replaced at day 5 and 10, and cells were collected with a 506 solution of PBS 5 mM EDTA (at 4°C) at day 15 for flow cytometry analysis. progenitors were added the following day in each well. Half of the medium was 511 replaced in both the top and bottom well at day 5 and 10. For GM-CSF blocking experiments, 512 2 µg/ml human GM-CSF neutralizing antibody (R&D cat. #AF-215-SP) and isotype control 513 (R&D cat. #AB-108-C) were added to the culture medium. The presence of human GM-CSF 514 in the supernatant of eMSCs co-cultures with CD34 + HSPCs was assessed by enzyme-linked 515 immunosorbent assay (ELISA) using the human GM-CSF ELISA MAX kit (Biolegend) as 516 per manufacturer's instructions. 517 RNA sequencing and data processing 518 RNA sequencing analysis was performed in two independent experiments. 519 In the first experiment, human cDC1s and cDC2s from peripheral blood of n=3 healthy 520 individuals and in vitro generated CD141 + Clec9A + , CD14 -CD1c + CD206and CD14 -521 CD1c + CD206 + cells from n=3 independent cord blood donors were FACS sorted. Up to 100 522 cells/subset were collected in lysis buffer (Takara Clontech) containing RNAse inhibitors. 523 RNAseq libraries were prepared using Labcyte Echo 525 contactless liquid handling system 524 (Labcyte Inc). In brief, ERCC mix (Thermo Fisher) was added to each sample and first strand 525 full length cDNA was generated with a modified protocol of the SMARTseq v4 Ultra Low 526 Input RNA Kit (Takara Clontech) using poly dT primers and a template switching oligo. Full 527 length cDNA was amplified using SeqAmp™ DNA Polymerase (Takara Clontech). 12 ng of 528 amplified cDNA from each sample was used to generate non-stranded RNA libraries using a 529 modified protocol of the Ovation Ultralow System V2 1-96 kit (NuGEN). In brief, amplified 530 cDNA was fragmented through sonication on Covaris E220 (Covaris Inc), repaired and 531 polished followed by ligation of indexed adapters. Adapter ligated cDNA were pooled before 532 25 final amplification to add flow cell primers. Libraries were sequenced on HiSeq2500 533 (Illumina Cambridge) for 100 cycles PE in Rapid mode. The raw sequencing data was 534 initially processed using open source, web-based platform Galaxy (version 18.05.rc1) 535(https://usegalaxy.org). Reads were filtered for quality with more than 80% of the sequence 536 having quality score > 33 using FastQC tool. Mapping against reference genome was 537 performed with Hisat2 to the hg38 human genome. Adapter sequences were detected 538 automatically with TrimGalore!. Reads under 20bp were discarded. All processed sequencing 539 files were imported in Partek® Flow® software (Partek Inc., build 7.0.18.0514) and the gene 540 count data was normalised using FPKM.541In the second experiment, human CD5 -cDC2, CD5 + cDC2, pDC and pre/AS-DC from 542 peripheral blood of n=3 healthy individuals and cDC2, pDC and pre/AS-DC generated both 543 in vivo and in vitro from n=2/3 independent cord blood donors were FACS sorted. Between 544 100 and 1000 cells/subset were collected in TRIzol ® (Thermo Fisher) and stored at -80°C.

FIGREF22.text: average gene expression of n=3 blood donors for cDC1s, n=2 blood donors for cDC2 and 554 n=3 cord blood units for in vitro generated subsets were used for RNA-seq data analysis.555 Hierarchical clustering was performed in Morpheus (Broad Institute, enrichment analysis (GSEA) (www.broad.mit.edu/gsea) 60 was used to assess the 559 expression of gene signatures specific for blood cDC1, cDC2, DC3, pDC and AS-DC in in 560 vitro and in vivo generated subsets. To simultaneously visualize pairwise comparisons of 561 transcriptomes from cord blood-derived cDCs, the BubbleMap module of BubbleGum 62 was 562 used. Results were considered significant when the p value was below 0.05 and the FDR 563 (false discovery rate, q) value was below 0.25. The GSEA was performed using previously 564 published gene signatures defining blood cDC1, cDC2, DC3, pDC and AS-DC 21 as well as 565 newly generated signatures using the GeneSign module of BubbleMap 62 (Supplementary566

FIGREF23.text: 568 using the "Min(test) vs Max(ref)" statistical method with a minimal linear fold change = 2 569 and a maximal FDR = 0.01. 570 Heatmaps displaying the expression pattern of gene signatures for cDC1, CD1c+ cells, pDC, 571AS-DC and cDC2 were generated using Morpheus (Broad Institute, 572 https://software.broadinstitute.org/morpheus/).573The 2000 genes defining the "in vitro culture imprinting" were identified using Morpheus as 574 the mean difference of expression values between two groups: the in vitro generated cells 575 (including cDC1, cDC2 CD206and cDC2 CD206 + ) versus ex vivo-isolated subsets (blood 576 cDC1 and blood cDC2).577The 2872 genes defining the "in vivo signature" were identified by DEG analysis using the R578 package DESeq2 (version 1.24.0) 77 with a Benjamin-Hochberg p-value correction 78 579 (Log2FC>1.5, adjusted p-value<0.01). The volcano plot displaying the differentially 580 27 expressed genes between in vivo and in vitro differentiated cDC2 was generated analysis was performed using ConsensusPathDB (cpdb.molgen.mpg.de) 80 and 584 WikiPathways database. 585 Mass cytometry staining, barcoding, acquisition and data analysis 586 For mass cytometry, pre-conjugated or purified antibodies were obtained from Invitrogen, 587 Fluidigm (pre-conjugated antibodies), Biolegend, eBioscience, Becton Dickinson or R&D 588 Systems as listed in Supplementary Table 3. For some markers, fluorophore-or biotin-589 conjugated antibodies were used as primary antibodies, followed by secondary labeling with 590 anti-fluorophore metal-conjugated antibodies (such as the anti-FITC clone FIT-22) or metal-591 conjugated streptavidin, produced as previously described 81 . Briefly, 3x10 6 cells/well in a U-592 bottom 96 well plate (BD Falcon) were washed once with 200 µL FACS buffer (4% FBS, 593 2mM EDTA, 0.05% Azide in 1X PBS) and then stained with 100 µL 200 µM cisplatin 594 (Sigma-Aldrich) for 5 min on ice to exclude dead cells. Cells were then incubated with anti-595 CADM1-biotin antibody in a 50 µL reaction for 30 min on ice. Cells were washed twice with 596 FACS buffer and incubated with 50 µL heavy-metal isotope-conjugated secondary mAb 597 cocktail for 30 min on ice. Cells were then washed twice with FACS buffer and once with 598 PBS before fixation with 200 µL 2% paraformaldehyde (PFA; Electron Microscopy 599 Sciences) in PBS overnight or longer. Following fixation, the cells were pelleted and 600 resuspended in 200 µL 1X permeabilization buffer (Biolegend) for 5 minutes at room 601 temperature to enable intracellular labeling. Cells were then incubated with metal-conjugated 602 anti-CD68 in a 50 µL reaction for 30 min on ice. Finally, the cells were washed once with 603 permeabilization buffer and then with PBS before barcoding.

FIGREF24.text: final concentration of 0.5 mM. Similarly, DOTA-maleimide (DM)-linked metal barcodes 608 were prepared by dissolving DM (Macrocyclics) in L buffer (MAXPAR) to a final 609 concentration of 1 mM. RhCl3 (Sigma) and isotopically-purified LnCl3 was then added to the 610 DM solution at 0.5 mM final concentration. Six metal barcodes were used: BABE-Pd-102, 611 BABE-Pd-104, BABE-Pd-106, BABE-Pd-108, BABE-Pd-110 and DM-Ln-113. 612 All BABE and DM-metal solution mixtures were immediately snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen 613 and stored at -80 o C. A unique dual combination of barcodes was chosen to stain each sample. 614 Barcode Pd-102 was used at 1:4000 dilution, Pd-104 at 1:2000, Pd-106 and Pd-108 at 1:1000, 615 Pd-110 and Ln-113 at 1:500. Cells were incubated with 100 µL barcode in PBS for 30 min on 616 ice, washed in permeabilization buffer and then incubated in FACS buffer for 10 min on ice. 617 Cells were then pelleted and resuspended in 100 µL nucleic acid Ir-Intercalator (MAXPAR) 618 in 2% PFA/PBS (1:2000), at room temperature. After 20 min, cells were washed twice with 619 FACS buffer and twice with water before a final resuspension in water. In each set, the cells 620 were pooled from all samples, counted, and diluted to 0.5x10 6 cells/mL. EQ Four Element 621 Calibration Beads (DVS Science, Fluidigm) were added at a 1% concentration prior to 622 acquisition. Cell data were acquired and analyzed using a CyTOF Mass cytometer 623 (Fluidigm). 624 The CyTOF data were exported in a conventional flow-cytometry file (.fcs) format and 625 normalized using previously-described software 82 . Events with zero values were randomly 626 assigned a value between 0 and -1 using a custom R script employed in a previous version of 627 mass cytometry software 83 . Cells for each barcode were deconvolved using the Boolean 628 gating algorithm within FlowJo. The CD45 + Lin (CD7/CD14/CD15/CD16/CD19/CD34) -629 29 HLA-DR + population of PBMC were gated using FlowJo and exported as an .fcs file. Marker 630 expression values were transformed using the logicle transformation function 84 . Random 631 sub-sampling without replacement was performed to select 20,000 cell events. 632 The transformed values of sub-sampled cell events were then subjected to Uniform Manifold 633 Approximation and Projection (UMAP) dimension reduction 64, 85 using all markers. We used 634 the 2.4.0 release of UMAP, implemented in Python, but executed through the reticulate R 635 package to interface R objects with Python. For both mass-cytometry datasets we used 636 UMAP using 15 nearest neighbors (nn), a min_dist of 0.2 and euclidean distance. 637 Heatmaps displaying mean intensity values of CyTOF data were generated using Morpheus 638 (Broad Institute, https://software.broadinstitute.org/morpheus/). 639 Human dendritic cell differentiation in vivo 640 Human cord blood-derived CD34 + hematopoietic cells (5-15x10 4 cells/plug) were injected 641 subcutaneously along with engineered stromal cells (1:1 to 1:5 ratio HSPC/MS5) in 200 μl of 642 ice-cold Matrigel ® (BD Biosciences). Mice were sacrificed at day 12 of differentiation by 643 cervical dislocation and Matrigel ® plugs were collected. Subcutaneous Matrigel ® plugs were 644 recovered, cut in pieces and incubated in HBSS (Life Technologies) 1% FBS, 0.37 U/ml 645 Collagenase D (Roche), 10 µg/ml DNaseI (Roche) and 1 mg/ml Dispase (Sigma-Aldrich) for 646 30 minutes at 37°C. After digestion, plugs were smashed on a 100 μm strainer (Corning) and 647 cells were collected and resuspended in FACS buffer for flow cytometry analysis.

FIGREF25.text: were fixed with 1% PFA (Alfa Aesar) for 1hr at 4°C, washed and incubated in 650 34% sucrose solution (Sigma-Aldrich) overnight at 4°C. Plugs were embedded in Cryomatrix 651 (Thermo Fischer) and frozen for cryostat sectioning (9 µm-thick). Sections were 652 permeabilized using 0.5% saponin (Sigma-Aldrich), 2% BSA (Sigma-Aldrich), 1% FBS 653 (Life Technologies) for 30 minutes at room temperature. For human DCs staining, plug 654 sections were incubated with 1% rat anti-mouse CD16/32 (homemade) for 30 minutes to 655 block unspecific binding sites. Sections were labeled overnight at 4°C with mouse anti-656 human CD1c-PE (L161, Biolegend) or mouse anti-human Clec9A-PE (8F9, Biolegend) 657 followed by incubation for 1hr at room temperature with goat anti-mouse Cy3 (Jackson 658 laboratory). After extensive washes, sections were labeled with mouse anti-human CD45-659 APC (HI30, Biolegend) for 1hr at room temperature. For human CD34 + progenitors staining, 660 plugs sections were labeled overnight with purified mouse anti-human CD45 (HI30, 661 Biolegend) followed by 1hr incubation at room temperature with goat anti-mouse Cy3. After 662 extensive washes, sections were labeled with mouse anti-human CD34-APC (561, 663 Biolegend) for 1hr at room temperature. To detect murine endothelial cells, sections were 664 labeled with purified rat anti-mouse CD31 (MEC13.3, Biolegend) and mouse anti-human 665 CD45 (HI30, Biolegend) overnight followed by 1hr incubation at room temperature with goat 666 anti-mouse Cy3 (Jackson laboratory) and goat anti-rat Cy5 (Jackson laboratory). All sections 667 were labeled with Hoechst (Molecular Probes, Thermo Fisher) for nuclei staining 5 minutes 668 at room temperature and mounted with Prolong diamond (Thermo scientific). Slides were 669 imaged using a SP5 (Leica) and analyzed with Fiji software.

CTV-labeled T cells were then isolated using a Pan naïve T cell 677 isolation kit (Miltenyi Biotec) according to manufacturer's instructions and isolation purity graphs each dot represents an independent cord blood donor and lines represent the 683 median value.
